title: Comment on "Earthquakes Descaled"
summary:
We show that Bak et al.'s unified scaling law cannot be trivially explained
by a single Omori aftershock sequence. On the contrary, the spatial
heterogeneity of seismicity plays a fundamental role in the unified scaling
law, which implies that the law provides a way to quantify seismic patterns in
space.

Lindman et al. [1] have used a nonhomogeneous Poisson process with a modified Omori rate, r(t) ≡ dn/dt =
rM (1 +t/c)−p, to model earthquake occurrence. We are going
to show that contrary to claims in Ref. [1], this extremely simple description is incomplete in order to explain Bak et al.'s
unified scaling law [2].
We generalize Lindman et al.'s model by introducing an
r−dependent waiting-time probability density of the form

Poisson process of Ref. [1], given by γ = 1 and a = 1 (both
parameters linked by normalization). The probability density

In fact, the power law for long times [Eq. (4)], was established in Ref. [3] for Southern California, but without relating it to the spatial heterogeneity of seismicity. The universal
value of the exponent 2 + α , found in Ref. [4] analyzing diverse seismic catalogs, would imply the universality of seismicity spatial heterogeneities. In consequence, Bak et al.'s
unified scaling law provides a way to measure these properties and is far from being as trivial as suggested by Lindman
et al.'s approach.
The model presented here is still too simple for real seismicity, but provides a clear visualization of its complexity and
the fundamentals of the unified scaling law of earthquakes.
